en.value: Could you shine the [k]torch[/k] over here? I can't find my sleeping bag.
campsite
We use could have, may have and might have when we are less certain about our deduction.
A foam sleeping mat is very light to carry.
[k]I[/k] [k]can't[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]been listening,[/k] [k]I don't remember anything.[/k]
In this case, the [k]whale[/k] could have been too old or maybe ill. Or maybe have been hunting squid or fish and got too close to the coast.
sleeping bag
Camper vans  provide transport and sleeping accommodation.
I thought I'd packed them but I haven't seen them anywhere.
Grammar: Making deductions II
sleeping mat
David
Shall we go camping?
We should pitch our tent under that tree for shade.
To be honest, this is not a major threat to any species as a whole, unlike the massive harm caused by overfishing and pollution.
This is a two-man tent.
Dolphins are able to maintain certain communication with humans.
They must have been swimming, their towels are wet.
The sentence talks about past actions.
camper van
Whales and [k]dolphins[/k] are sensitive to sonar and often move quickly away from it. Because they are confused, they sometimes end up too close to land.
Derrick must have gone out, his car isn't here. My friend can't have been hungry, he didn't finish his dinner.
I'm with [k]marine biologist[/k] Dr. Holly Taylor. Dr. Taylor, do you know what caused this whale to become stranded on the beach?
What are [k]marine conservationists[/k] doing to prevent things like this happening in the future?
Select the words in the correct order.
Some people say that military equipment sometimes causes whales to swim too close to a [k]coastal zone[/k]? Do you think this is a possibility?
Past deduction - can not finish
Seabirds have adapted to life within the marine environment.
marine plants
He [k]must have[/k] been shopping, the fridge is full of food.
can't have
the seabirds
marine animals
You can sing songs around the campfire.
marine biologist
I saw it next to the food earlier, have you checked over there?
coastal zone
Reporter
Marine plants, such as seaweed and other algae are found close to the shoreline.
The speaker is unsure about the deduction he is making.
We [k]might have driven|may have driven[/k] too far, but I'm not sure.
Dr. Holly Taylor
I would love to be a marine biologist.
Talking about nature and outdoor activities - Deductions (must have / can’t be)

She can't have... (more certain she didn't)
She must have... (more certain she did)
She may have / might have / could have... (less certain)
Past deduction - may drive
Paula can't be in, her light is off.
Camping
campfire
It's important to have a map and a compass.
whale
Lots of coral reef needs protecting from humans.
have
She [k]can't have[/k] enjoyed the job if she quit so soon.
They might have gone for a walk, they said they wanted to do that.
must
shark
No, sorry about that. Next year we're going to hire a [k]camper van[/k] for our holiday! That'll be much more comfortable!
Some marine animals are extremely dangerous.
The campsite has many facilities for children.
Fill in the gaps with the correct letters.
Select the correct option.
Emma
Lots of effort is being made to find and rescue animals like this whale when they get too close to the shore and stop them from dying.
She [k]might have[/k] gone out. I'm not sure.
Select the correct word(s) to fill the gap.
Listen to the dialogue and fill in the gaps.
Marine Life
Fill in the gap using the hint.
dolphin
[k]They[/k] [k]might[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]moved[/k] [k]house,[/k] [k]I haven't seen them for ages.[/k]
pitch the tent
Whales are marine mammals.
coral reef
My friend can't have been hungry, he didn't finish his dinner.
[k]We[/k] [k]must[/k] [k]have[/k] [k]been[/k] [k]tired,[/k] [k]we went straight to sleep.[/k]
He can't have made dinner, the fridge is empty.

I can't have been listening, I don't remember anything.
We must have been tired, we went straight to sleep.
must be shut
It's cold. I'm going to get into my sleeping bag.
You might need a torch at night.
compass
Do you think more should be done to stop [k]marine animals[/k], such as whales and dolphins, from dying on our beaches?

We use the past participle form of the main verb after 'can't have', 'must have' etc. 
'Can't have' is the opposite of 'must have'. We don't generally use 'mustn't have' for deduction.
Memorise the word(s) and listen to the example.
I [k]could have left[/k] my wallet at home. I remember seeing it on my bed.
Past deduction - can leave
You can't have been [k]having[/k] fun if you left that early.
tent
Ocean habitats are very varied.
must have
The door [k]must have shut[/k] in the wind. Do you have a key?
ocean habitats
rucksack
I know! We should have set off earlier and got here before it got dark.
Sharks are thought to have a keen sense of smell.
It's almost impossible to [k]pitch the tent[/k] in the dark! I can't see anything.
True or false?
We can make deductions about the past by using must have and can't have. We do this when we have some evidence (in the present or past) that allows us to make a deduction about events of the past.
Ah yes, here it is. Thanks. Did you remember the [k]sleeping mats[/k]?
They [k]can't have finished[/k] class, they're all still inside the school.
My things won't fit into my rucksack!
No, they're not over here by the pillows either. We must have left them. Oh dear, it's not going to be a particularly comfy night.
Derrick must have gone out, his car isn't here.
torch
In the ocean you can see many beautiful marine plants and animals like dolphins and sharks. I am interested in dolphins, because they are very intelligent and unusual.
What are some things you can see in the ocean? What marine creature interests you most, and why?
The coastal zone is believed to only make up 10% of the ocean environment.

A: Has he finished work?
B: Yes, he [k]must have[/k].
